title: 17 Revamped Haircut Trends Set To Define The New Year, According To Top Stylists
text:
17 Revamped Haircut Trends Set To Define The New Year, According To Top Stylists

This year hasnâ€™t exactly left us lacking in haircut trends. In August, we fell for the â€œthickeningâ€ cut â€” a strategically layered style that adds major volume to fine strands â€” and in November, we spotted the J-shape haircut, with its loose layers that fall effortlessly into that curved silhouette. But with a shiny new year on the horizon, a fresh wave of haircut ideas is on the way.

Whether youâ€™re eyeing the â€œcloudâ€ bob or craving something shorter, like a pixie crop, thereâ€™s a trend for everyone.

Ahead, top hairstylists from London to NYC share the cuts set to define 2026 â€” and beyond.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Varsity Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by steph hui (@stxph.h)

Hair artist Tom Smith describes the varsity bob as a choppy, chin-skimming cut with subtle layers and a center part. The inspo? Steph Hui and Millie Bobby Brown. â€œPolished but never prissy, it carries a cool collegiate energy â€” youthful without being childish and preppy without being stiff,â€ says Smith. While the movement might look undone, itâ€™s actually intentional and well-maintained, adds Smith, thanks to the invisible layers through the mid-lengths and ends that create that flicky volume.

Gucci Bangs

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Dimitris Giannetos (@dimitrishair)

â€œGucci bangs feel very fashion-forward â€” and powerful,â€ says celebrity hairstylist and colorist, Dimitris Giannetos. He recalls creating the softly-parted, slightly grown-out look for Demi Moore ahead of her role as the fictional character Barbara Gucci in the short film The Tiger. â€œTo achieve this look, ask for wispy curtain bangs just below the brows with face-framing pieces towards the ears,â€ recommends Giannetos. The key? â€œAvoid a blunt cut by adding some variety to the length of the bangs across the face,â€ he says.

The Clean Cut Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Deborah Iona | Beauty & Lifestyle (@deborahiona)

â€œAnok Yaiâ€™s striking short bob, complete with a blunt fringe, highlights the boldness of this style,â€ says celebrity hairdresser Lorraine Dublin. â€œItâ€™s a sharp, chin-skimming bob paired with a clean fringe, and itâ€™s set to stand out this winter.â€ Why? It has a strong, modern silhouette, Dublin explains, yet still feels polished and low-maintenance. We also love the look on content creator Deborah Iona.

The Ripped Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Catherine Gibbs (@ccatherinee.g)

Nick Stenson, celebrity hairstylist and founder of Nick Stenson Beauty, highlights the â€œrippedâ€ bob as the standout cut of winter 2026. â€œBobs are making a comeback because their clean, structured shape offers a chic, low-maintenance look that pairs perfectly with cold-weather layers,â€ says Stenson. The ripped bob, however, is a more interesting, layered take, thanks to softly separated ends created with a texturizing technique where the hair is chopped into vertically. This cut by Catherine Gibbs is perfect.

The Feathered Shag

A post shared by âœ§âœ§ ğ•½ğ–„ğ•°ğ•¹ğ•¹ğ•° ğ•¾ğ•¹ğ•ºğ–‚ âœ§âœ§ (@ryennesnow.hair)

The shag is set to take on a much gentler image in 2026, according to Neale Rodger, style director at STIL salon in London. â€œThink soft, feathered layers that build volume and create easy movement,â€ says Rodger, like this look by Ryenne Snow. Rodger adds that itâ€™s the kind of cut that still looks intentional even as it grows out. â€œItâ€™s a brilliant choice for medium to thick hair,â€ continues Rodger, â€œespecially if thereâ€™s already some natural wave or texture to play with.â€ Guiding your stylist is simple: â€œAsk for feathered layers throughout, soft ends, and a length that sits somewhere between the neck and shoulders,â€ advises Rodger.

â€™60s Bangs

A post shared by âœ§âœ§ ğ•½ğ–„ğ•°ğ•¹ğ•¹ğ•° ğ•¾ğ•¹ğ•ºğ–‚ âœ§âœ§ (@ryennesnow.hair)

The â€™70s have had their time in the sun. Now, itâ€™s 1960â€™s time to shine, and bangs are leading the resurgence, says Ricky Walters, founder and creative director of Salon 64. â€œThe new incarnation is all about boldness: think thick, heavy, statement-making fringes taken surprisingly far back into the crown,â€ says Walters. He adds, â€œThis isnâ€™t a whisper of a fringe; itâ€™s a full-volume curtain that instantly reshapes the face, adding drama, mystery, and a touch of French-girl rebellion.â€ Walters says that cutting it with plenty of density â€” adding bulk through techniques like point cutting and texturizing â€” prevents it from slipping into anything too dated. Hairstylist Ryenne Snow always nails it.

The Power Pixie

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Iris Law ğŸ§¼ğŸ§Š (@lirisaw)

The power pixie has Florence Pugh, Glenn Close, and Iris Law to thank for its meteoric rise. â€œThis is a cropped, layered pixie thatâ€™s sharp, sculpted, and deliberately androgynous,â€ says Smith. Its key characteristics? â€œEnough length and the top and front to allow for versatile styling,â€ adds Smith, who calls it the ultimate anti-blowout style. â€œThis is great for finer hair types and those who want more lift, as it helps to contour the jawline and cheekbones when long enough to be tucked behind the ears,â€ says Smith. Asking for it couldnâ€™t be simpler: â€œAsk for close layering and texture that can shift from matte and punkish by day to polished and glossy at night,â€ advises Smith â€” and donâ€™t forget the longer, swooping bangs.

The Bubble Cut Blowout

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Dimitris Giannetos (@dimitrishair)

The name sounds complicated, but the result speaks for itself. Itâ€™s essentially a soft blowout with rounded, bouncy ends, explains Giannetos, who recently debuted the look on Amal Clooney. â€œIt works well on long, layered hair, about 6-8 inches from the shoulder. This look enhances body, adds movement, and makes the blowout feel thicker and more voluminous,â€ says Giannetos. â€œI like to take a 1.25â€ Bio Ionic Curler to the ends to lock in the rounded shape.â€

The Polished Pixie

A post shared by SIA | Lifestyle â€¢ Outfits â€¢ Beauty (@sialuxe_)

Super-short styles are still trending, says Dublin, but the polished pixie is having a moment. Just look to content creator Sia. â€œItâ€™s perfect if you want a low-maintenance cut that holds up through the colder, wetter months,â€ Dublin says, adding, â€œIf youâ€™re not ready for a full chop, a pixie-style wig gives you the same look with zero commitment.â€

The Shaggy Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Akesha Reid (@keeksreid)

The shaggy bob is not only effortlessly chic, says Dublin, but itâ€™s practical for winter and spring. â€œThe layers add movement and texture â€” great under scarves or hats â€” while still looking polished for work or evening plans,â€ adds Dublin. Grab a hydrating hair cream like PATTERN by Tracee Ellis Ross Palo Santo Styling Cream and let your natural texture do its thing. This cut on Keeks Reid is beautiful.Â

Mussed-up texture is in this season, says Stenson, and while the classic shagâ€™s layering technique is making a comeback, itâ€™s being reimagined for 2026 with modern softness and volume. â€œEven better, itâ€™s flexible across hair types,â€ he adds. â€œA shag is great for anyone with thick hair because it removes weight and bulk. If you have finer hair, ask for a modern micro-shag or wolf-shag with strategic layering that adds volume and texture without making the hair look sparse,â€ advises Stenson. This cut on Linasha never fails to inspire.Â 

The Shaggy Lob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Catherine Gibbs (@ccatherinee.g)

â€œThe textured lob [aka long bob] will continue its quiet takeover,â€ says Rodger. â€œItâ€™s mid-length, slightly undone, and effortlessly cool â€” the kind of cut that behaves beautifully through winter,â€ he adds. Itâ€™s also a seasonal all-rounder, and easy to air-dry in the warmer months, too. â€œI love how it slips under scarves and coats without losing shape, and it gives hair that natural, lived-in movement,â€ continues Rodger, who says itâ€™s perfect for wavy and lightly curly hair. â€œAsk your stylist for a neck-to-shoulder graze with feathered, textured ends, and a soft, natural finish,â€ suggests Rodger. Hairstylist Catherine Gibbs nails the look here.

The One-Length Bob

The 2026 update is lighter than its previous counterpart, says Walters, and it sits in what he refers to as the magic zone: â€œJust above the collarbone and never shorter than the jawline,â€ adds Walters, like this cut by Miho Mai. â€œThis sweet spot creates a clean, graphic silhouette without sacrificing softness.â€ What gives it a modern edge is the invisible layering: â€œThese are subtle, sliced-in shorter pieces hidden underneath,â€ says Walters. â€œThese secret layers act like built-in movement, allowing the bob to swing, breathe, and catch the light in all the right ways.â€

Curtain Bangs 2.0

A post shared by Charlotte | Macomb MI Hairstylist (@charlottexstyles)

If theyâ€™re not cut properly, curtain bangs can look blocky and unnatural, failing to blend into the rest of your lengths. Thatâ€™s why Stenson suggests asking for â€œtexturizedâ€ curtain bangs. Texturized bangs are cut with techniques that soften the fringe and remove bulk, so they fall more naturally. â€œYour stylist will assess the density of your hair to ensure your bangs are proportionate to your face,â€ says Stenson. â€œBangs are especially a great choice for those with fine or thin hair and looking to bring some volume to their look. Theyâ€™re truly versatile enough to suit all face shapes.â€ Take inspiration from this cut by @charlottexstyles on Instagram.

The Chin-Length Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Dimitris Giannetos (@dimitrishair)

Gianettos says that thereâ€™s something so chic about a sharp bob that grazes the chin and that it can elevate any outfit. â€œIt feels very confident, effortless, cool-girl,â€ says Giannetos. â€œIt can be worn wavy for an everyday style or straight for a very sleek, edgy look,â€ â€” much like this cut on Meredith Duxbury. â€œI like to use Lâ€™Oreal Parisâ€™ Sleek It Iron Straight Hairspray to tame any frizz that distracts from the moment,â€ says Giannetos.

The Bixie Cut

The bixie â€” bob meets pixie â€” is heading into 2026 with us, and for good reason: itâ€™s soft, wearable, and short enough to feel fresh, says Rodger. â€œThis is a sweet spot between a bob and a pixie, and itâ€™s ideal for anyone tempted to go shorter without committing to a full pixie,â€ says Rodger. title: Your Horoscope This Week: December 21 To 27
text:
Your Horoscope This Week: December 21 To 27

Welcome to a major transition week, R29 babes. On December 21st, the solstice strikes and Capricorn Season officially begins, marking one of the most powerful energetic pivots of the year. In astrology, solstices are threshold moments: they represent extremes of light and dark, visibility and invisibility, action and rest. What shifts at the solstice is not effort, but orientation: we move from Sagittariusâ€™s freedom-seeking, exploratory energy into Capricornâ€™s grounded commitment to self, legacy, and responsibility. Weâ€™re also coming off the Sagittarius New Moon, making this an ideal week to set intentions if you havenâ€™t yet, or to recommit to the ones that truly matter.

Before the sun even enters Capricorn, though, thereâ€™s an important emotional undercurrent. In the early hours of December 21st at 5:08 a.m. EST, Jupiter in Cancer squares Chiron in Aries, creating a moment of tension between sensitivity and action. Jupiter in Cancer amplifies emotional truth, memory, and the need for safety, while Chiron in Aries exposes wounds around identity, courage, and self-assertion.

As the week unfolds, the Capricorn influence deepens. How can you embody the stability, integrity, and commitment youâ€™re craving? Capricorn Season isnâ€™t about deprivation â€” itâ€™s about self-respect. And this solstice week sets the tone.

title: Emma Mackey & Jamie Lee Curtis On Grief, Trauma & What Comes Next
text:
Emma Mackey & Jamie Lee Curtis On Grief, Trauma & What Comes Next

Spoilers ahead. Is it actually possible to recover from childhood trauma, or will the effects linger forever? Thatâ€™s the question Ella McCay asks, the new film from three-time Academy Award winner James L. Brooks (Terms of Endearment, As Good as It Gets). Following Ella McCay, played by Emma Mackey (Barbie, Sex Education), the 34-year-old lieutenant governor juggles the grief of her motherâ€™s death as well as a strained relationship with her father, with help from her caring Aunt Helen, played by Jamie Lee Curtis (Freaky Friday, Everything Everywhere All At Once).

Ella exhibits signs of people-pleasing behaviour in both her work and personal life after watching her father repeatedly cheat on her mother. She seems doomed to repeat the cycle, trying her best to have a â€œnormalâ€ marriage with her husband Ryan (Jack Lowden), which results in her overcompensating to make him happy. Principal psychologist Carly Dober from Enriching Lives Psychology tells Refinery29 this could be due to a need to â€œestablish a false sense of safetyâ€ and notes itâ€™s a common trauma response. â€œPeople-pleasing can also be linked to emotional dependency. [This] occurs when someone has unmet psychological needs that they may try to satisfy within close interpersonal relationships,â€ Dober says. â€œ[It] is a pattern of behaviours people may engage in to get others to like them, and to avoid rejection, criticism, or embarrassment. Itâ€™s linked to traits such as depression, anxiety and low self-esteem.â€

Mackey confirms that Ella McCay is a study of the â€œhuman conditionâ€, and tells us thatâ€™s partly what drew her to the role. â€œThe film is very much about cycles and cycles being broken, or not in a few cases, and about what you decide to make of yourself,â€ Mackey tells R29. Throughout the film, her Aunt Helen acts like a driving force in her life, and calls out the behaviour of Ellaâ€™s husband. Mackey notes it can be â€œunsettlingâ€ to have somebody by your side pointing out flaws or truths you want to avoid, but in some ways, thereâ€™s a â€œcomfortâ€ to it as well. â€œSheâ€™s the truth sayer, and says the uncomfortable thing when I donâ€™t want to hear it, and itâ€™s absolutely spot on every time,â€ Mackey says. â€œAnd we all need one of those people in our lives just to bring us back to whatâ€™s real and to make us think about itâ€¦ and then weâ€™ve got to work with it, work through it.â€

Thereâ€™s one particular line in the family that gives audiences a closer look into Ellaâ€™s psyche, and thatâ€™s when she admits she adores her husband because he comes from a â€œnormal familyâ€. She deems it â€œnormalâ€ because his parents are still married, unlike Ellaâ€™s own experience. Itâ€™s telling that she prioritizes this above other traits he possesses, such as his manipulative tendencies. By making choices rooted in trauma, sheâ€™s ended up in the midst of another unhappy cycle. Curtis says these family dynamics and trauma portrayed in Ella McCay are what make this film feel so rooted in reality. â€œThatâ€™s what makes movies so relatable, and particularly family movies, is that you can sit there and watch a movie as a family and realise your family is different from the family youâ€™re watching on screen, but there are a lot of similarities,â€ Curtis explains. â€œHopefully, families have an Aunt Helen, that person in your life who champions you even though youâ€™re getting battered.â€

As difficult as it is to see Ellaâ€™s life crumble around her during the film, Mackey says itâ€™s important to stumble at times so you can succeed in the future. â€œUnless you [stumble], you have no perspective, and you donâ€™t know whatâ€™s important,â€ Mackey says. â€œYou donâ€™t want to seek or search what youâ€™re curious about if you donâ€™t stumble a couple of, or a lot of times.â€

And while the drama-comedy tugs at the heartstrings, Curtis says she wants audiences to take away one thing. â€œThere is no opposite word for trauma, but hope comes close,â€ she says, quoting the film. â€œThat, to me, is where you understand that even with traumatic experiences, hope for the future, hope for your family, hope for the world, hope for potential. All of it comes pretty close to being a counterpoint to the bad things that have happened.â€

Ella McCay is in theaters now.

title: I Got A Korean Digital Perm â€” & Itâ€™s My Most Complimented Hairstyle Yet
text:
I Got A Korean Digital Perm â€” & Itâ€™s My Most Complimented Hairstyle Yet

Iâ€™ve wanted a perm for years now, but with the amount of damage my hair went through with multiple bleaching sessions (I had a pastel pink phase), I had to wait until I had a full head of virgin hair. When I told one of my best friends I was finally about to get a Korean digital perm, she was horrified and said I would probably regret it. Look, I get it. The perm is controversial. You probably instantly think of giant fluffy â€™80s hairdos or tight ringlets. But unlike traditional perms, the Korean style uses heat technology to create softer curls, which appear more natural.

My hair is naturally straight with a slight wave that becomes more obvious the shorter it is. I also have incredibly thick and heavy lengths, so when I use a curling iron, I have to douse my hair in hairspray to ensure the curls donâ€™t fall out. As somebody whoâ€™s always wanted curly hair, getting a Korean digital perm was an easy decision. Both my older brother and sister have perms, so I was confident going in. I went to my hairstylist Chloe Choi at Chloe Hair & Beauty, but Korean perms are becoming more popular in salons worldwide. Together, we discussed what could be done while looking at some photos Iâ€™d brought along for inspiration. She confirmed that my hair type is frizzy with a slight natural wave, and we settled on a direct digital perm to create some tighter curls.

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Rachel & Jeremy ğŸŒTravel Couple (@thekiwicouple)

There are a handful of benefits to a Korean perm: â€œNormal perms mean sometimes you canâ€™t see definition in the curls, but with digital perms you can,â€ said Choi, who used to work at a salon in Myeong-dong, South Korea, before moving to Sydney. Before we started with my perm, Choi recommended starting with a Japanese Tokio Treatment, which helps repair hair from the inside out. By replenishing it with keratin, it strengthens, moisturizes, and smooths each hair strand. â€œA lot of people really like this brand,â€ Choi explained. â€œItâ€™s a repairing treatment, and it adds moisture to your hair. Some people will come back after their perms get dry and then have another Tokio Treatment,â€ she told me.

What is a Korean digital perm?

Choi started by washing my hair and applying the Tokio Treatment, before setting up an additional hot steam treatment to help hydrate each strand of hair. The steam â€œopensâ€ up the hair cuticle, allowing moisture and products to absorb. After getting a small trim where Choi enhanced my layers, my hair was rewashed with a pH-balancing shampoo. She then followed this with a Korean product that protects the hair from the typically harsh perming chemicals used to break and reset the protein bonds in the hair. Itâ€™s this which results in a curl or wave.

Next, Choi placed the digital perm lotion directly onto my hair and rolled sections tightly into curlers to take shape, then plugged each curler in, allowing them to be set by heat. Choi told me that my hair was â€œstrongâ€, so we had to wait over 20 minutes before it started to set. Then we headed back to the basin where my hair was washed with a neutralizer, snapping the protein bonds back into place. Et voilÃ ! I was now a member of the curly hair club.

How do you style a Korean digital perm?

To style my hair, Choi gave me a slight side part, which created a more voluminous look from the scalp. She added some curl cream to define the waves and recommended investing in some good products. Her top tip? â€œIf you have frizzy hair and you want to style it while itâ€™s dry, mix curl cream with a little bit of water in your palms before using it on your hair,â€ she said. â€œThis helps get rid of the frizz and also hydrates it.â€

Styling a digital perm at home isnâ€™t too difficult, either. I have a sensitive scalp, so Iâ€™ve purchased some sulfate-free shampoo and conditioner. Sulfate-free products will also prolong the permâ€™s results. I wash my hair with lukewarm water in the shower before scrunching up the curls with a microfiber towel. Next, I add curl cream to define my curls and continue to scrunch them upwards, before using my Laifen Hair Dryer (a Dyson dupe) with a diffuser to blow-dry the perm in place.

How long do you have to wait after a Korean perm to wash your hair?

Your stylist will let you know how long you should go without washing your perm Ã  la Legally Blonde. For me, I had to wait a minimum of 48 hours before washing my hair after getting my digital perm.

Can a Korean digital perm cause damage to your hair?

A digital perm uses chemicals that alter your hair structure and heat to set it in place, so most hairstylists recommend doing it on virgin hair. They also recommend steering clear of perms if your hair is bleached, chemically straightened, or very fine. Bleach in particular weakens the hair by breaking its bonds, which means perm solutions donâ€™t interact well with it. Ultimately, the hair often lacks the strength to hold a set shape, making the process more likely to fail.

How do you take care of your Korean perm?

Getting a perm might increase frizz if your hair is prone to it. This is because when the chemical process weakens the hair, it also lifts the cuticle. Iâ€™d recommend investing in a silk pillowcase or a silk bonnet to help keep the frizz to a minimum. Also try a moisturizing leave-in hair product like K18 Biomimetic Hairscience Molecular Repair Hair Oil, which contains peptides, avocado oil, and squalane to help smooth and repair the broken bonds that lead to frizz.

How do you ask for a Korean digital perm?

Doing your research and choosing a properly qualified expert is key. I would also recommend bringing reference photos so your stylist can see which kind of curl you are after. Itâ€™s also important to discuss your hair health and type, and whether a perm will cause extra frizz or breakage for you.

I can safely say that having a digital perm has led to more conversations about my hair than Iâ€™ve had in years â€” and it looks much healthier than my pastel pink or purple-silver combo. Iâ€™m able to wake up with voluminous hair ready to go, and if I need to style it a little bit, I can just use some curl cream, which also helps hydrate my hair. Itâ€™s less maintenance than colored hair, so Iâ€™m convinced Iâ€™m a perm girl for life.
